qas.question: when did the US pass the Homestead ACt?
how much land did the Homestead Act allow a person to claim?
how long did the person have to live on the land?
when was the Kinkaid Act brought about?
the dominion act was passed in what year
In what year was the Kinkaid Act repealed?
In what year was the Dominions Lands Act repealed?
In what year did the relatively wet years of the Great Plains end?
What number of people established homestead in Canada?
How many homesteaders failed to establish cultivated land?

context: To allow for agricultural development of the Great Plains and house a growing population, the US passed the Homestead Acts of <a0_0><b5_0>1862<b5_0/><a0_0/>: it allowed a settler to claim <a1_0>up to 160 acres<a1_0/> (65 ha) of land, provided that he lived on it for a period of <a2_0>five years<a2_0/> and cultivated it. The provisions were expanded under the Kinkaid Act of <a3_0><b6_0>1904<b6_0/><a3_0/> to include a homestead of an entire section. <b8_0><b9_0>Hundreds of thousands<b9_0/><b8_0/> of people claimed such homesteads, sometimes building sod houses out of the very turf of their land. Many of them were not skilled dryland farmers and failures were frequent. Much of the Plains were settled during relatively wet years. Government experts did not understand how farmers should cultivate the prairies and gave advice counter to what would have worked[citation needed]. Germans from Russia who had previously farmed, under similar circumstances, in what is now Ukraine were marginally more successful than other homesteaders. The Dominion Lands Act of <a4_0><b7_0>1871<b7_0/><a4_0/> served a similar function for establishing homesteads on the prairies in Canada.
